pullRequest.body:
The main PR for the `have` vs `let` linter.

The `have` vs `let` linter emits a warning on `have`s introducing a hypothesis whose
Type is not `Prop`.
There are three settings:
* `0` -- inactive;
* `1` -- active only on noisy declarations;
* `2` or more -- always active.
The default value is `1`.

The linter lints mathlib, but, by default, it is silent on complete proofs.

#12157 is an experiment showing what changes the linter would suggest on mathlib.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
As a test, I ran the linter with the "new" monad on a fresh copy of mathlib: I wanted to make sure that it picked up the same issues that the previous version of the linter noticed.

The result is an improvement: I think that they flag essentially the same issues and the new monad pretty-prints better.  However, there is an overflow that I cannot debug.  You can see its effects in [this failed linting step](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8717184502/job/23911967424?pr=12204).

The two places that I identified are a `run_cmd` in `Mathlib/Data/UInt.lean` and a `local notation3` in `Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.lean`.

Looking at the places where I had to unset the linter, I am guessing that this is just a matter of a slowdown: `notation3`, `theorem`, run_command` all appear among the list of unlinted commands.


```lean
diff --git a/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.lean b/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.lean
index 7742e87568..3ea8cbfefe 100644
--- a/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.lean
+++ b/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.lean
@@ -56,8 +56,10 @@ open scoped BigOperators TensorProduct
 
 section notation_weightSpaceOf
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false
 /-- Until we define `LieModule.weightSpaceOf`, it is useful to have some notation as follows: -/
 local notation3 "ùïé("M", " œá", " x")" => (toEndomorphism R L M x).maximalGeneralizedEigenspace œá
+set_option linter.haveLet true
 
 /-- See also `bourbaki1975b` Chapter VII ¬ß1.1, Proposition 2 (ii). -/
 protected theorem weight_vector_multiplication (M‚ÇÅ M‚ÇÇ M‚ÇÉ : Type*)
diff --git a/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/Restrict.lean b/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/Restrict.lean
index 11aecab1ec..a209fdc975 100644
--- a/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/Restrict.lean
+++ b/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/Restrict.lean
@@ -35,10 +35,12 @@ section
 
 variable (X : Scheme)
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false in
 /-- `f ‚Åª¬π·µÅ U` is notation for `(Opens.map f.1.base).obj U`,
   the preimage of an open set `U` under `f`. -/
 notation3:90 f:91 "‚Åª¬π·µÅ " U:90 => (Opens.map (f : LocallyRingedSpace.Hom _ _).val.base).obj U
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false in
 /-- `X ‚à£_·µ§ U` is notation for `X.restrict U.openEmbedding`, the restriction of `X` to an open set
   `U` of `X`. -/
 notation3:60 X:60 " ‚à£_·µ§ " U:61 => Scheme.restrict X (U : Opens X).openEmbedding
diff --git a/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Covering/Vitali.lean b/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Covering/Vitali.lean
index 536f1a2dbd..e976f9c92f 100644
--- a/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Covering/Vitali.lean
+++ b/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Covering/Vitali.lean
@@ -192,6 +192,7 @@ theorem exists_disjoint_subfamily_covering_enlargment_closedBall [MetricSpace Œ±
     exact ‚ü®c, cu, by simp only [closedBall_eq_empty.2 h'a, empty_subset]‚ü©
 #align vitali.exists_disjoint_subfamily_covering_enlargment_closed_ball Vitali.exists_disjoint_subfamily_covering_enlargment_closedBall
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false in
 /-- The measurable Vitali covering theorem. Assume one is given a family `t` of closed sets with
 nonempty interior, such that each `a ‚àà t` is included in a ball `B (x, r)` and covers a definite
 proportion of the ball `B (x, 3 r)` for a given measure `Œº` (think of the situation where `Œº` is ... -/
diff --git a/Mathlib/RingTheory/Kaehler.lean b/Mathlib/RingTheory/Kaehler.lean
index 1796e93347..052ed3af6a 100644
--- a/Mathlib/RingTheory/Kaehler.lean
+++ b/Mathlib/RingTheory/Kaehler.lean
@@ -481,10 +481,12 @@ noncomputable def KaehlerDifferential.kerTotal : Submodule S (S ‚Üí‚ÇÄ S) :=
       Set.range fun x : R => single (algebraMap R S x) 1)
 #align kaehler_differential.ker_total KaehlerDifferential.kerTotal
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false
 unsuppress_compilation in
 -- Porting note: was `local notation x "ùñ£" y => (KaehlerDifferential.kerTotal R S).mkQ (single y x)`
 -- but not having `DFunLike.coe` leads to `kerTotal_mkQ_single_smul` failing.
 local notation3 x "ùñ£" y => DFunLike.coe (KaehlerDifferential.kerTotal R S).mkQ (single y x)
+set_option linter.haveLet true
 
 theorem KaehlerDifferential.kerTotal_mkQ_single_add (x y z) : (zùñ£x + y) = (zùñ£x) + zùñ£y := by
   rw [‚Üê map_add, eq_comm, ‚Üê sub_eq_zero, ‚Üê map_sub (Submodule.mkQ (kerTotal R S)),
diff --git a/Mathlib/SetTheory/Game/Basic.lean b/Mathlib/SetTheory/Game/Basic.lean
index ec92a0d3dc..6f3259b0d9 100644
--- a/Mathlib/SetTheory/Game/Basic.lean
+++ b/Mathlib/SetTheory/Game/Basic.lean
@@ -519,6 +519,7 @@ theorem quot_mul_neg (x y : PGame) : ‚ü¶x * -y‚üß = (-‚ü¶x * y‚üß : Game) :=
   Quot.sound (mulNegRelabelling x y).equiv
 #align pgame.quot_mul_neg SetTheory.PGame.quot_mul_neg
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false in
 @[simp]
 theorem quot_left_distrib (x y z : PGame) : (‚ü¶x * (y + z)‚üß : Game) = ‚ü¶x * y‚üß + ‚ü¶x * z‚üß :=
   match x, y, z with
@@ -689,6 +690,7 @@ theorem one_mul_equiv (x : PGame) : 1 * x ‚âà x :=
   Quotient.exact <| quot_one_mul x
 #align pgame.one_mul_equiv SetTheory.PGame.one_mul_equiv
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false in
 theorem quot_mul_assoc (x y z : PGame) : (‚ü¶x * y * z‚üß : Game) = ‚ü¶x * (y * z)‚üß :=
   match x, y, z with
   | mk xl xr xL xR, mk yl yr yL yR, mk zl zr zL zR => by
```
I think the issue is that `InfoTree.foldInfoM` is a hack, and the right way to do it is to modify `InfoTree.foldInfo` to be monadic.
Eric, fair enough!  Do you still think that this version is better or should I revert it to the one with the handcrafted `MetaM` state?

### PR summary [94894a93a9](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12190/commits/94894a93a9ed6639bb2a76782b95663d8f79c792)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic.Linter | 12 | 14 | +2 (+16.67%) |
| Mathlib.Tactic | 2144 | 2146 | +2 (+0.09%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
There are 4048 files with changed transitive imports: this is too many to display!

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ InfoTree.foldInfoM`
`+ areProp_toFormat`
`+ ghi`
`+ haveLetLinter`
`+ isHave?`
`+ nonPropHaves`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by joneugster.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10284620382/job/28461038267)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10284620382/job/28461037484)

Looks quite clean to me! However, I did not quite figure out how level `1` is supposed to work, see comments below.

I also have some remaining thoughts on whether it's actually useful to enforce this linter in mathlib, but if I understand it correctly, the current PR does not and only shows the warnings while working on a statement, which seems nice.

@joneugster, thank you very much for the review!  I acted on all your comments and they were all great!

I also left some clarifications in the various discussions.

As discussed in the other PR; I think you want `ContextInfo.runMetaM` here. You can get the context you need by using [Lean.Elab.InfoTree.foldInfo](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Lean/Server/InfoUtils.html#Lean.Elab.InfoTree.foldInfo)

Eric, I tried to use this, but I cannot see how.  From the `InfoTree`s, I could get a `PartialContextInfo`, produce a `ContextInfo` using `.mergeIntoOuter?`, but then to use `Lean.Elab.InfoTree.foldInfo` I still need a `LocalContext` (that I could probably fetch inside the `MetavarContext` embedded into to `ContextInfo`), but I do not know how to find which goals are post-`have` and which ones are pre-`have`, since they seem to be all mashed together.

On the other hand, if I am at a `.node` of the InfoTree`, I can do what I did, but there I do not seem to have access to a `(Partial)ContextInfo`, so I would not know where to start...

I came up with this:
```lean
def InfoTree.foldInfoM {Œ± m} [Monad m] (f : ContextInfo ‚Üí Info ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí m Œ±) (init : Œ±) :
    InfoTree ‚Üí m Œ± :=
  InfoTree.foldInfo (fun ctx i ma => do f ctx i (‚Üê ma)) (pure init)

/-- returns the `have` syntax whose corresponding hypothesis does not have Type `Prop` and
also a `Format`ted version of the corresponding Type. -/
partial
def nonPropHaves : InfoTree ‚Üí CommandElabM (Array (Syntax √ó Format)) :=
  InfoTree.foldInfoM
    (fun ctx info args => return args ++ (‚Üê do
      let .ofTacticInfo i := info | return #[]
      let stx := i.stx
      if exclusions.contains stx.getKind then return #[]
      unless isHave? stx do return #[]
      let mctx := i.mctxAfter
      let mvdecls := (i.goalsAfter.map (mctx.decls.find? ¬∑)).reduceOption
      let _ : Ord MetavarDecl := { compare := (compare ¬∑.index ¬∑.index) }
      -- we extract the `MetavarDecl` with largest index after a `have`, since this one
      -- holds information about the metavariable where `have` introduces the new hypothesis.
      let largestIdx := mvdecls.toArray.qsort (¬∑.index > ¬∑.index)
      -- the relevant `LocalContext`
      let lc := (largestIdx.getD 0 default).lctx
      -- and the last declaration introduced: the one that `have` created
      let ld := (lc.lastDecl.getD default).type
      -- now, we get the `MetaM` state up and running to find the type of `ld`

      ctx.runMetaM lc do
        let typ ‚Üê inferType (‚Üê instantiateMVars ld)
        if ! typ.isProp then
          return #[(stx, ‚Üê ppExpr ld)]
        else
          return #[]))
    #[]
```
Eric, I factored out your monadic `foldInfo`: I am still trying to wrap my head around it, but it looks great, thanks!

You can use `unless` here to flatten the control flow:
```suggestion
    let nargs := (‚Üê args.toArray.mapM nonPropHaves).flatten
    let .ofTacticInfo i := i | return nargs
    let stx := i.stx
    if exclusions.contains stx.getKind then return #[] else
    unless isHave? stx do return nargs
    let mctx := i.mctxAfter
    let mvdecls := (i.goalsAfter.map (mctx.decls.find? ¬∑)).reduceOption
    let _ : Ord MetavarDecl := { compare := (compare ¬∑.index ¬∑.index) }
    -- we extract the `MetavarDecl` with largest index after a `have`, since this one
    -- holds information about the metavariable where `have` introduces the new hypothesis.
    let largestIdx := mvdecls.toArray.qsort (¬∑.index > ¬∑.index)
    -- the relevant `LocalContext`
    let lc := (largestIdx.getD 0 default).lctx
    -- and the last declaration introduced: the one that `have` created
    let ld := (lc.lastDecl.getD default).type
    -- now, we get the `MetaM` state up and running to find the type of `ld`
    liftCoreM <| MetaM.run' (ctx := { lctx := lc }) (s := { mctx := mctx }) <| do
      let typ ‚Üê inferType (‚Üê instantiateMVars ld)
      if ! typ.isProp then
        return nargs.push (stx, ‚Üê ppExpr ld)
      else return nargs
```
Thanks!  This was already included in the code above, which I used.

```suggestion
    let .original .. := stx.getHeadInfo | return #[] 
```

Eric, this is essentially the only extra change that I added to your code.  Without it, the linter was still flagging, e.g., `replace`.  I think that the reason is that it was descending into the implementation of `replace`, rather than "staying on the surface".
What's the `Ord` instance for if the following line uses `(¬∑.index > ¬∑.index)` anyways?
Very good point!  I think that I was initially using something other than an `Array` and then the internal sorting required an `Ord` instance.  I removed it, since it no longer seems to be needed.

`declsOld` and `oldDecls` is a bit unfortunate naming. Am I understanding this correct that `oldDecls` are all `LocalDecl`s that are introduced newly by the tactic in question? If so, wouldn't `declsNew` be more fitting?

Yes, in development, I had lots of different lists floating around, before focusing on the ones that are now present.

I renamed to `newDecls` the one that was called `oldDecls` and switched all variable names to the more Saxon `oldXxx`/`newXXX`.

I'm a bit confused about linting level `1`:

If I just comment the `#guard_msgs in`, the linter does not highlight the `have`, and neither does it if I add `set_option linter.haveLet 1`. Only if `set_option linter.haveLet 2` is chosen the linter will display the warning.

Was your intention not that having `set_option linter.haveLet 1` together with `noise` somewhere in the proof would cause the linting warning to be displayed?

I am also confused by this: you understood correctly what the linter is supposed to do.  However, the message that `noise` was logging was somehow invisible to the linter (I do not undestand why, probably because it is "inside" the `TacticM` and does not reach the external state).

Anyway, I replaced `noise` with a macro that simply introduces a vacuous `sorry` and now, hopefully the tests align with what I intended and also what you expected!

```suggestion
/--
warning: '_zero : Nat' is a Type and not a Prop. Consider using 'let' instead of 'have'.
[linter.haveLet]
-/
#guard_msgs in
set_option linter.haveLet 2 in
example : True := by
  have ‚ü®_zero, _‚ü© : Fin 1 := ‚ü®0, Nat.zero_lt_one‚ü©
  exact .intro
```

Is this what you want?
Indeed it is!  I would have thought that I tried this, but your code works!

Is there a way to guard an unfinished proof, like this one without `tauto`? If I understand your motivation for level `1` correctly, it's also to trigger on unfinished proofs, isn't it?

I expected that if I delete the `#guard_msgs` here and then delete `tauto` that the linter warnings would pop up. Did I understand this wrongly?

The linter emits a warning if a declaration simultaneously does not have errors *and* yet emits messages.  Simply removing `tauto` leaves an `unsolved goals` *error*, so the linter shuts up.  If, instead, you replace `tauto` with `sorry`, then the linter will tell you that you should use `let`/`have`.

I could make the linter chatty also in the presence of errors, but I think that on an erroring declaration, the linter will yield dubious reports and would be simply extra noise.

ok. I somehow expect that an "unsolved goals" error behaves very similar to a "declaration uses sorry" warning in as many aspects as possible but I see that's not as easy with how messages are reported.

Looks good to me as is.
Is this just a limitation of the types that can be passed to a built in option?

Essentially yes. A `Lean.Option` is
```lean
/-- A strongly-typed reference to an option. -/
protected structure Option (Œ± : Type) where
  name     : Name
  defValue : Œ±
  deriving Inhabited
```
with an arbitrary type `Œ±`.  However, the `Option` is then stored in a `KVMap`, whose `Value`s need to be in a
```lean
/-- Value stored in a key-value map. -/
inductive DataValue where
  | ofString (v : String)
  | ofBool   (v : Bool)
  | ofName   (v : Name)
  | ofNat    (v : Nat)
  | ofInt    (v : Int)
  | ofSyntax (v : Syntax)
  deriving Inhabited, BEq, Repr
```
I felt that remembering `0`, `1` and `2` was easier than remembering three strings for the settings.
I guess it is discoverable but it would nice to have custom syntax for verbosity of things.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: have/let linter

nodes.body:
As a test, I ran the linter with the "new" monad on a fresh copy of mathlib: I wanted to make sure that it picked up the same issues that the previous version of the linter noticed.

The result is an improvement: I think that they flag essentially the same issues and the new monad pretty-prints better.  However, there is an overflow that I cannot debug.  You can see its effects in [this failed linting step](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8717184502/job/23911967424?pr=12204).

The two places that I identified are a `run_cmd` in `Mathlib/Data/UInt.lean` and a `local notation3` in `Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.lean`.

Looking at the places where I had to unset the linter, I am guessing that this is just a matter of a slowdown: `notation3`, `theorem`, run_command` all appear among the list of unlinted commands.


```lean
diff --git a/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.lean b/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.lean
index 7742e87568..3ea8cbfefe 100644
--- a/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.lean
+++ b/Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/Weights/Basic.lean
@@ -56,8 +56,10 @@ open scoped BigOperators TensorProduct
 
 section notation_weightSpaceOf
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false
 /-- Until we define `LieModule.weightSpaceOf`, it is useful to have some notation as follows: -/
 local notation3 "ùïé("M", " œá", " x")" => (toEndomorphism R L M x).maximalGeneralizedEigenspace œá
+set_option linter.haveLet true
 
 /-- See also `bourbaki1975b` Chapter VII ¬ß1.1, Proposition 2 (ii). -/
 protected theorem weight_vector_multiplication (M‚ÇÅ M‚ÇÇ M‚ÇÉ : Type*)
diff --git a/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/Restrict.lean b/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/Restrict.lean
index 11aecab1ec..a209fdc975 100644
--- a/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/Restrict.lean
+++ b/Mathlib/AlgebraicGeometry/Restrict.lean
@@ -35,10 +35,12 @@ section
 
 variable (X : Scheme)
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false in
 /-- `f ‚Åª¬π·µÅ U` is notation for `(Opens.map f.1.base).obj U`,
   the preimage of an open set `U` under `f`. -/
 notation3:90 f:91 "‚Åª¬π·µÅ " U:90 => (Opens.map (f : LocallyRingedSpace.Hom _ _).val.base).obj U
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false in
 /-- `X ‚à£_·µ§ U` is notation for `X.restrict U.openEmbedding`, the restriction of `X` to an open set
   `U` of `X`. -/
 notation3:60 X:60 " ‚à£_·µ§ " U:61 => Scheme.restrict X (U : Opens X).openEmbedding
diff --git a/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Covering/Vitali.lean b/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Covering/Vitali.lean
index 536f1a2dbd..e976f9c92f 100644
--- a/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Covering/Vitali.lean
+++ b/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Covering/Vitali.lean
@@ -192,6 +192,7 @@ theorem exists_disjoint_subfamily_covering_enlargment_closedBall [MetricSpace Œ±
     exact ‚ü®c, cu, by simp only [closedBall_eq_empty.2 h'a, empty_subset]‚ü©
 #align vitali.exists_disjoint_subfamily_covering_enlargment_closed_ball Vitali.exists_disjoint_subfamily_covering_enlargment_closedBall
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false in
 /-- The measurable Vitali covering theorem. Assume one is given a family `t` of closed sets with
 nonempty interior, such that each `a ‚àà t` is included in a ball `B (x, r)` and covers a definite
 proportion of the ball `B (x, 3 r)` for a given measure `Œº` (think of the situation where `Œº` is ... -/
diff --git a/Mathlib/RingTheory/Kaehler.lean b/Mathlib/RingTheory/Kaehler.lean
index 1796e93347..052ed3af6a 100644
--- a/Mathlib/RingTheory/Kaehler.lean
+++ b/Mathlib/RingTheory/Kaehler.lean
@@ -481,10 +481,12 @@ noncomputable def KaehlerDifferential.kerTotal : Submodule S (S ‚Üí‚ÇÄ S) :=
       Set.range fun x : R => single (algebraMap R S x) 1)
 #align kaehler_differential.ker_total KaehlerDifferential.kerTotal
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false
 unsuppress_compilation in
 -- Porting note: was `local notation x "ùñ£" y => (KaehlerDifferential.kerTotal R S).mkQ (single y x)`
 -- but not having `DFunLike.coe` leads to `kerTotal_mkQ_single_smul` failing.
 local notation3 x "ùñ£" y => DFunLike.coe (KaehlerDifferential.kerTotal R S).mkQ (single y x)
+set_option linter.haveLet true
 
 theorem KaehlerDifferential.kerTotal_mkQ_single_add (x y z) : (zùñ£x + y) = (zùñ£x) + zùñ£y := by
   rw [‚Üê map_add, eq_comm, ‚Üê sub_eq_zero, ‚Üê map_sub (Submodule.mkQ (kerTotal R S)),
diff --git a/Mathlib/SetTheory/Game/Basic.lean b/Mathlib/SetTheory/Game/Basic.lean
index ec92a0d3dc..6f3259b0d9 100644
--- a/Mathlib/SetTheory/Game/Basic.lean
+++ b/Mathlib/SetTheory/Game/Basic.lean
@@ -519,6 +519,7 @@ theorem quot_mul_neg (x y : PGame) : ‚ü¶x * -y‚üß = (-‚ü¶x * y‚üß : Game) :=
   Quot.sound (mulNegRelabelling x y).equiv
 #align pgame.quot_mul_neg SetTheory.PGame.quot_mul_neg
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false in
 @[simp]
 theorem quot_left_distrib (x y z : PGame) : (‚ü¶x * (y + z)‚üß : Game) = ‚ü¶x * y‚üß + ‚ü¶x * z‚üß :=
   match x, y, z with
@@ -689,6 +690,7 @@ theorem one_mul_equiv (x : PGame) : 1 * x ‚âà x :=
   Quotient.exact <| quot_one_mul x
 #align pgame.one_mul_equiv SetTheory.PGame.one_mul_equiv
 
+set_option linter.haveLet false in
 theorem quot_mul_assoc (x y z : PGame) : (‚ü¶x * y * z‚üß : Game) = ‚ü¶x * (y * z)‚üß :=
   match x, y, z with
   | mk xl xr xL xR, mk yl yr yL yR, mk zl zr zL zR => by
```
I think the issue is that `InfoTree.foldInfoM` is a hack, and the right way to do it is to modify `InfoTree.foldInfo` to be monadic.
Eric, fair enough!  Do you still think that this version is better or should I revert it to the one with the handcrafted `MetaM` state?

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |

Looks quite clean to me! However, I did not quite figure out how level `1` is supposed to work, see comments below.

I also have some remaining thoughts on whether it's actually useful to enforce this linter in mathlib, but if I understand it correctly, the current PR does not and only shows the warnings while working on a statement, which seems nice.

@joneugster, thank you very much for the review!  I acted on all your comments and they were all great!

I also left some clarifications in the various discussions.
